text: Since you already know how to program I'd recommend Dive Into Python.

The the video lectures from the Google python class:
http://code.google.com/edu/languages/google-python-class/index.html
Then head over to pyschools.com for some good practice.
I found The Python Cookbook useful when I was in a similar position.
It's pretty good at getting across how to "think Python" IMO.
Lutz has a new update forProgramming Python.
Dive into Python is also an excellent reference as stated above.

childList.text: Lutz has a new update forProgramming Python

text: Learning Python might be a good start.
It's a little old but the basics are mostly the same.
I guess I too had the same problem and I would suggest the best way is to experiment and whenever in doubt look at the official Python docs.

It is quite comprehensive for the beginners as well as for those learning Python for advanced usage.....Moreover there is a link for each function which describes its usage so I would say its the best for you....
Since you already know how to program in other imperative languages I'd just start with the (Python Language Reference)[http://docs.python.org/reference/index.html].
If you come across a construct that you can't understand from the reference then find the corresponding section of the tutorial.
After that, sections 1 - 3 of the [Library Reference](http://docs.python.org/library/index.html as well as the sections on sys, string, re, math, itertools, os, and types to start with.
After that, look at any other libraries you're particularly interested in.
If you already have some basic in programming, you may want to try this: pyschools
